vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**

Hi Team!

On Team object the parameter "i_cannot_create_jira_webhook_reasons" is not NULL and gets the following default states when called for all programs ["CANNOT_VIEW","FEATURE_GATED","PROGRAM_PERMISSION_REQUIRED"]

If a Company Program runs a Private Program or a Public On the "FEATURE_GATED" is missing (Since the feature is not gated anymore) and therefore an attacker can find if a Company is running a private program

##POC

* Company ██████ (not runnig private gives "i_cannot_create_jira_webhook_reasons":["CANNOT_VIEW","FEATURE_GATED","PROGRAM_PERMISSION_REQUIRED"]

* Company █████████ (running private) gives "i_cannot_create_jira_webhook_reasons":["CANNOT_VIEW","PROGRAM_PERMISSION_REQUIRED"]

* Even Company HackerOne  (running public) gives "i_cannot_create_jira_webhook_reasons":["CANNOT_VIEW","PROGRAM_PERMISSION_REQUIRED"]

All private programs and public has an overriden  "FEATURE_GATED" so you get the idea

#Solutiion

NULL the value maybe

PS: Thanks to @jobert who encouraged me to search deeper after the #347383 duplicate!

Thanks
**nismo**

## Impact

Knowing companies that run private programs on Hackerone
title: Team object in GraphQL that have a published external program may expose existence of a private program

activities.message:
Just a POC for the Team handle █████.

You may change thie value to any HackerOne companies listed on HackerOne and search for the absense of FEATURE_GATED declaring a PRIVATE running program as explained above

█████

Thanks again!

activities.message: Hi @nismo - thanks for your report. By looking at the code it seems that you may be mistaken. This only says something about the product edition the program uses. This may still be something worth fixing, but I don't think that this actually reveals the status of a program, since any sandbox program can pick any product edition. Let me know what you think. Thanks in advance and happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @nismo - thanks for your report. By looking at the code it seems that you may be mistaken. This only says something about the product edition the program uses. This may still be something worth fixing, but I don't think that this actually reveals the status of a program, since any sandbox program can pick any product edition. Let me know what you think. Thanks in advance and happy hacking!

activities.message:
@jobert 

Hi! Thanks for the fast reply!

I am pretty sure there is a disclosure based on the GRAPHQL reply on that particular parameter. Let me explain

* All others I_CAN_SOMETHING parameters (taken by GRAPHL full introspection schema query were NULLed
* Using a new user account all queries to PUBLIC programs running PRIVATES were missing "FEATURE GATED" as a reply for example (**█████**,**███**,**███**) so I quess THIS IS a disclosure, otherwise I could not tell the difference (for example █████, █████ etc DO return all answers without missing one.

Am I right to this? Shouldnt all companies showing as "EXTERNAL" reply with the same? Because the above POC shows a difference and I can tell that at least they are running a PRIVATE program.

Nevertheless I guess as pointed at first it should be NULLED

Thanks and keep up the great work!

Am I right to this? Shouldnt all companies showing as "EXTERNAL" reply with the same? Because the above POC shows a difference and I can tell that at least they are running a PRIVATE program.

Thanks and keep up the great work!

activities.message:
@jobert

For example (last one), **███** is an external program. ███
If you POST to /GRAPHQL requiring the response to  **"i_cannot_create_jira_webhook_reasons"** parameter you will get ["CANNOT VIEW", "PROGRAM PERMISSION REQUIRED"] with **"FEATURE GATED" MISSING!!!***

This is a 100% positive according to the above POC that **███████** is running a CONFIDENTIAL PRIVATE program on HackerOne!

Thanks again!!! Hope this will be triaged!

activities.message: Hi @nismo - ah, I get what you're saying! I'm still not entirely sure if this is a bug though. If someone has claimed their public Directory profile, they can still create a sandbox program and select any product edition there is. This means that you wouldn't be able to distinguish between the two. I'd agree that you could assume they have a program, but if you work under that assumption, you'd be able to reach out to them regardless when the program handle is taken on H1. Does that make sense? Let me know what you think and if I'm missing something. Thanks!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @nismo - ah, I get what you're saying! I'm still not entirely sure if this is a bug though. If someone has claimed their public Directory profile, they can still create a sandbox program and select any product edition there is. This means that you wouldn't be able to distinguish between the two. I'd agree that you could assume they have a program, but if you work under that assumption, you'd be able to reach out to them regardless when the program handle is taken on H1. Does that make sense? Let me know what you think and if I'm missing something. Thanks!

activities.message:
@jobert 

Thank for you new comments (again!!). I am happy you understand what I am trying  to show.

Even the `whitelisted_hackers` on #347383 (closed as a duplicate) is NOT an absolutely true factor that the PROGRAM is running a private (it would be a sandbox) you awarded a 2500$!! although for example ███████ or many other companies that show a NUMBER may be a SANDBOXED TEAM, so my report here is EXACTLY the same for another parameter!

*POC*

I got the external companies 536 companies list, feeded them through INTRUDER in Burp and asked in GRAPHQL for "i_can_not_create_jira_webhook_reasons" and "whitelisted_hackers" just to have a 100% INFORMATION DISCLOSURE!

This is a partial snapshot of the companies returned 

██████

As you may see from those two parameters I can  say if an EXTERNAL listed program is running a PRIVATE, maybe not 100% as you agreed but surely I proved to you that this is NOT accidental and you should definitely look at it and report NULL on your GRAPHQL.

**██████████, ██████, ██████████, ██████████, ██████████, ,███████, █████, ████████, ██████████ are running PRIVATES 100% and there response is missing "FEATURE GATED" missing** which means that THIS IS A INFORMATION DISCLOSURE rather than a side-effect

I do hope that this will be triaged too as i think i've proved that this parameter should be NULL and that a fix should be applied based on my report!

Thank you!

activities.message: Hi @nismo and @irvinlim - thanks to both of you for bringing this to our attention. We spent some time on this figuring out whether we should accept this under our bug bounty program. We determined that this does not have any impact, because there's no way to tell the difference between a sandboxed program or a private program (there are actually four states the program can be in). Because of that, we do not deem it a guarantee that the programs listed above are running private programs. However, while looking at this we realized that we don't seem using this attribute anymore and seems to be technical debt instead. I'll pass this along to the team that is responsible for it and ask them to remove the attribute altogether. This report will not be eligible for a bounty, but I'll throw in some swag for bringing this to our attention. This report will be marked as resolved, so both of you will get reputation and recognition in our Hall of Fame. Thanks again, it's much appreciated. Good luck and happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @nismo and @irvinlim - thanks to both of you for bringing this to our attention. Because of that, we do not deem it a guarantee that the programs listed above are running private programs. However, while looking at this we realized that we don't seem using this attribute anymore and seems to be technical debt instead. I'll pass this along to the team that is responsible for it and ask them to remove the attribute altogether. This report will not be eligible for a bounty, but I'll throw in some swag for bringing this to our attention. This report will be marked as resolved, so both of you will get reputation and recognition in our Hall of Fame. Thanks again, it's much appreciated. Good luck and happy hacking!

activities.message:
Hi @jobert, thanks so much for spending time to go through our reports. For the benefit of @nismo, I will clarify my doubts here as well.

I think the thing that I (and perhaps @nismo) are most confused about is the distinction between private and sandboxed programs. I understand from your program's policy that information disclosures that do not distinguish between these types of programs are considered out of scope. 

Seeing that the previous report #342978, in which both @nismo and I had filed duplicates on, made use of a similar property (in that case `whitelisted_hackers`) to identify if an external program was actually running a private program, what is the exact difference between that report and this report, _in terms of distinguishing between sandboxed and private programs_?

Based on your explanation, let me try to see if what I understood is correct: 

1. Sandboxed programs cannot accept submissions from the general public, while "private programs" (in your terminology) refers to programs that _do_ accept submissions, regardless of whether the program is viewable (i.e. external program).
2. The `whitelisted_hackers` field only applies to "private programs", since this count supposedly only counts invited researchers.
3. Meanwhile, the absence of `FEATURE_GATED` from `i_cannot_create_jira_webhook_reasons` can show that a program exists under the handle, regardless if it is sandboxed or "private".

Therefore, what you're saying is that:

1. _There is no vulnerability_ if we can tell if an external program is running a program that hasn't been launched
2. _There is a vulnerability_ if we can tell whether an external program is "private" or sandboxed, i.e. whether they are a paying customer

I think the reason why we are confused is that we don't have any examples of what a sandboxed (and not "private") program looks like. In addition, in report #342978 you said (and I quote):

> this issue can be used to determine whether external programs in our Directory are running private programs

This led us to believe that there is indeed a vulnerability if we could tell if an external program was running a program under the handle, since we could already tell that some of them (notably ████, or companies with their own bug bounty programs like ██████ and █████████) would not have a private program in HackerOne. The findings in this report as well as my own duplicate in #349172 were based on this assumption.

It would be helpful if you could confirm/provide a precise definition of the four states of a program you are referring to, in order to avoid future invalid reports.

Thanks once again, and sorry for the long reply!

I think the thing that I (and perhaps @nismo) are most confused about is the distinction between private and sandboxed programs. I understand from your program's policy that information disclosures that do not distinguish between these types of programs are considered out of scope.

Seeing that the previous report #342978, in which both @nismo and I had filed duplicates on, made use of a similar property (in that case whitelisted_hackers) to identify if an external program was actually running a private program, what is the exact difference between that report and this report, in terms of distinguishing between sandboxed and private programs?

Based on your explanation, let me try to see if what I understood is correct:

  1. Sandboxed programs cannot accept submissions from the general public, while "private programs" (in your terminology) refers to programs that do accept submissions, regardless of whether the program is viewable (i.e. external program).
  2. The whitelisted_hackers field only applies to "private programs", since this count supposedly only counts invited researchers.
  3. Meanwhile, the absence of FEATURE_GATED from i_cannot_create_jira_webhook_reasons can show that a program exists under the handle, regardless if it is sandboxed or "private".

Therefore, what you're saying is that:

  1. There is no vulnerability if we can tell if an external program is running a program that hasn't been launched
  2. There is a vulnerability if we can tell whether an external program is "private" or sandboxed, i.e. whether they are a paying customer

I think the reason why we are confused is that we don't have any examples of what a sandboxed (and not "private") program looks like. In addition, in report #342978 you said (and I quote):

this issue can be used to determine whether external programs in our Directory are running private programs

This led us to believe that there is indeed a vulnerability if we could tell if an external program was running a program under the handle, since we could already tell that some of them (notably ████, or companies with their own bug bounty programs like ██████ and █████████) would not have a private program in HackerOne. The findings in this report as well as my own duplicate in #349172 were based on this assumption.

It would be helpful if you could confirm/provide a precise definition of the four states of a program you are referring to, in order to avoid future invalid reports.

Thanks once again, and sorry for the long reply!

activities.message:
@jobert and @security

I am surprised to see triaging but not accepting the report for the $2500 award saying its not eligible.

Perhaps HackerONE Team can explain how the #342978 referring the  parameter "whitelisted_hackers" got triaged and awarded as MEDIUM RISK, since on that report  it is also uncertain to distinguish PRIVATE vs SANDBOXED programs as well, based on the parameter awarded.

* For ex. ████ "whitelisted_hackers" count_total is 1. Does it mean it runs a PRIVATE program? Certainly NO

Nevertheless it got triaged and awarded, got a MEDIUM RISK and I filed a duplicate on that.

My POC in here has both of the parameters so you can distinguish and tell the difference. But my report here was set a risk of NONE?

Sorry to ask again, since I didn't get an answer and still wondering.

Does #342978 actually distinguish SANDBOX or PRIVATE as written in that report while rewarding? Or as I ask above is ██████████ running a PRIVATE based on that report? If in doubt then then I guess that my report here should be eligible as well, dont you think?

@jobert I certainly hope you will reconsider the report to be eligible and equally risked to "whitelisted_hackers" impact, since I know and trust your professionalism and honesty in judging reports equally.

PS: Thanks to the researcher who backed up my report for the  award eligibility. It is appreciated to see a researcher backing up the eligibility of report of another.

Thanks again!

Thanks again!

activities.message:
@irvinlim @jobert 

As i invested a a lot of time on this GRAPHQL issue (and others) long story short is that the `whitelisted_hackers` is not an exclusive  on private programs only parameter as I proved and I attach one here for all to see.

The whole disagreement  here is based on @jobert written reward and risk explanation (also mentioned by you) on #342978 that 
>  this issue can be used to determine whether external programs in our Directory are running private programs

meaning that the "whitelisted_hackers" parameter can be used to distinguish which EXTERNAL programs are running privates (where he uses CAN instead of MAY and without ever mentioning distinguished PRIVATE vs SANDBOX ones as he did it later and only in this report).

Based on that and the motivation to search for other parameters, my work and report (and your duplicate) was focused on finding a different parameter able to do exactly the same and claiming information disclosure and bounty.

I attach the proof to see that they are numerous EXTERNAL programs (taken from the 536 listed) having "whitelisted_hackers" parameter numbers which ARE SANDBOXed but not PRIVATE, but based on  @jobert explanation on #342978 these are privates.

███████

So is obvious that the real problem is that HACKERONE decided to reward the `whitelisted_hackers` report and not the `i_cannot_create_jira_webhook_reasons` report giving a $2500 bounty to one and nothing to the other, which is unfair.

Would it be unfair if HACKERONE didnt reward the #342978 and if the Team did the research and provided the same answer as in here and  the proof  attached? Maybe, but the fact is that they did NOT.

So I honestly hope that @jobert will at least understand my point and misjudgement and reward the bounty to be equally fair to the reports at least since it is triaged afterall and a similar report was rewarded.

Waiting on an answer on this

Thanks

activities.message:
I mean I have no horse in this race but I think the issues reveal very similar information. One could argue this one has a lower impact as it may reveal an external program running a private whereas the whitelisted hacker one reveals it 100% of the time. If I had a guess this should lower the impact to maybe low but still in scope. 

AS far as I can tell the real issue here is i_cannot_create_jira_webhook_reasons discloses if a program has Jira set up regardless of it's state. As long as it is not feature gated we know it the program uses H1 platform integration with Jira.

activities.message:
Hi all - thanks for the thoughtful responses, it's appreciated. Let me start by saying that we're not here to not pay you for your reports. However, let me elaborate on the situation: all your reports are claiming that you can determine whether an external program is also running a private program on HackerOne. I agree that this may be true in some cases, but there's no guarantee.

Any company can claim an external program page on HackerOne. They can do this without running a program. When they've claimed a program page, they can maintain their policy in the Directory to make sure it's up to date with their own. It also means that the community can't contribute anymore to that page. When they've claimed the page, they can create a program in our demo environment. Within our demo environment, you can freely pick a product edition. Depending on which one they pick to poke around, you'll see the `FEATURE_GATED` error being returned. It may also mean that they're running a private program. Because of the number of different cases you can't guarantee that they are running a program. If your goal is to enumerate all the programs I don't see how this would get you any closer to your goal, because you could reach out to the company anyway (asking for invites isn't tolerated though).

It reveals about the same amount of information as signing in with `user@some-sso-enabled-domain.com` and getting redirected to a company's SSO provider or trying to sign up for a user with a company name and realizing it's already been taken (anyone could've taken this). Long story short: this doesn't meet the requirements for a bounty, but like I said, we'll go ahead and award swag for it. Thanks for your understanding!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi all - thanks for the thoughtful responses, it's appreciated. Let me start by saying that we're not here to not pay you for your reports. However, let me elaborate on the situation: all your reports are claiming that you can determine whether an external program is also running a private program on HackerOne. I agree that this may be true in some cases, but there's no guarantee.

Any company can claim an external program page on HackerOne. They can do this without running a program. When they've claimed a program page, they can maintain their policy in the Directory to make sure it's up to date with their own. It also means that the community can't contribute anymore to that page. When they've claimed the page, they can create a program in our demo environment. Within our demo environment, you can freely pick a product edition. Depending on which one they pick to poke around, you'll see the FEATURE_GATED error being returned. It may also mean that they're running a private program. Because of the number of different cases you can't guarantee that they are running a program. If your goal is to enumerate all the programs I don't see how this would get you any closer to your goal, because you could reach out to the company anyway (asking for invites isn't tolerated though).

It reveals about the same amount of information as signing in with user@some-sso-enabled-domain.com and getting redirected to a company's SSO provider or trying to sign up for a user with a company name and realizing it's already been taken (anyone could've taken this). Long story short: this doesn't meet the requirements for a bounty, but like I said, we'll go ahead and award swag for it. Thanks for your understanding!

It's interesting how ge got added to the report 3 days before me. I guess new reports are ordered by reputation.

activities.message:
Hi @nismo ,

I just checked with my own sandboxed program. I should state that this was not obviously clear at first but you CAN select any program state you want in a sandboxed environment. I realized this after reading the long explanation. So I was able to select enterprise edition which removed the FEATURE_GATED response from my program ████  even when I queried from a non admin account. Which means anyone can create programs that also do not return the FEATURE-GATED response. 

However a sandboxed environment in basic edition can invite hackers as they want. Which means if I invite 5 of my friends whitelisted_hackers would show 5. I think you need both of the info disclosures to make sure someone is running a private program. For example we know ████████ has a private program because they have more than 1 whitelisted hacker and they are not feature-gated so they must be paying H1 for a private program.

The thing is basic edition can invite hackers but will be feature gated but sandboxed program can try out product edition with 1 whitelisted hacker. Unless I'm missing some sort of functionality this is the behavior.

I'm sure H1 staff will explain it better than me.

activities.message:
@emitrani 

You are answering on a wrong question. 

* I know that `i_cannot_create_jira_webhook_reasons` DOES NOT distinguish between PRIVATE vs SANDBOX

The question is for a company that has `whitelisted_hackers`=3 how can you tell it runs a PRIVATE vs SANDBOX by seeing only this parameter (as H1 stated that this can be used to tell the difference).
 That is what I am asking to understand the MEDIUM severity of `whitelisted_hackers` parameter.

activities.message:
I understand your question but the thing is they are not going to take back a reward they issued, personally as far as I can tell you can invite people to your sandboxed program and increase whitelisted_hackers, however I don't know of anyway to put your sandboxed program in the external directory.

So if you go to directory and select external program(https://hackerone.com/directory?query=type%3Aexternal) and go through all of those with whitelisted_hackers you can enumerate which one of those have private programs by observing a response `>1` . I also don't think this is significant info disclosure but the reward is already issued.

activities.message:
explicitly stating to answer @nismo's question:

`whitelisted_hackers` can *only* be non-zero for verified, non-sandboxed programs. If you manage to find a program that *does not* show up when you go to hackerone.com/<handle>, but that *does* show `whitelisted_hackers` with a non-zero value in GraphQL, you've found a private program!

When inviting hackers for a sandboxed program, we block the actual invite, and kick off our program validation process, to verify that you are actually representing the company you say you are. This means that a sandboxed team will **never** have any whitelisted reporters.

This means that `whitelisted_hackers` can 100% be used to distinguish between private and sandboxed teams, which is why we decided to award that report a bounty.

Cheers, 
Dirk
activities.markdown_message:
explicitly stating to answer @nismo's question:

whitelisted_hackers can only be non-zero for verified, non-sandboxed programs. If you manage to find a program that does not show up when you go to hackerone.com/<handle>, but that does show whitelisted_hackers with a non-zero value in GraphQL, you've found a private program!

When inviting hackers for a sandboxed program, we block the actual invite, and kick off our program validation process, to verify that you are actually representing the company you say you are. This means that a sandboxed team will never have any whitelisted reporters.

This means that whitelisted_hackers can 100% be used to distinguish between private and sandboxed teams, which is why we decided to award that report a bounty.

Cheers,
Dirk

activities.message:
@dirk

Hi! 
Thanks but your statement **IS different** than @jobert explanation on rewarding that report stating
> this issue can be used to determine whether external programs in our Directory are running private programs

So joberts references that the 536 external companies on the H1 Directory can be state determined and hence my questions that █████ or ██████████ having NON_ZERO `whitelisted_hackers` are running privates or no.


OTOH, your statement is different saying that if a company **does not** show up on hackerone.com/handle? 
Well this is not an external at first, and secondly IF it is a company (Either a PRIVATE or SANDBOX company you will be redirected to SIGN IN ) in order to get a GRAPHQL token as well.

On that case the GRAPHQL program will not let you query a company you are not invited (OBJECT NOT FOUND) nor a STATE will be viewed (and actually shows a contact suppport error insted of NULLing the fiedd).
On the other hand if you are invited you could see the WHITELISTED hackers even on sandbox. At least on a sandboxed one that I did my checks)

So am I missing something?

Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
@dirk

Hi!
Thanks but your statement IS different than @jobert explanation on rewarding that report stating

this issue can be used to determine whether external programs in our Directory are running private programs

So joberts references that the 536 external companies on the H1 Directory can be state determined and hence my questions that █████ or ██████████ having NON_ZERO whitelisted_hackers are running privates or no.

OTOH, your statement is different saying that if a company does not show up on hackerone.com/handle?
Well this is not an external at first, and secondly IF it is a company (Either a PRIVATE or SANDBOX company you will be redirected to SIGN IN ) in order to get a GRAPHQL token as well.

On that case the GRAPHQL program will not let you query a company you are not invited (OBJECT NOT FOUND) nor a STATE will be viewed (and actually shows a contact suppport error insted of NULLing the fiedd).
On the other hand if you are invited you could see the WHITELISTED hackers even on sandbox. At least on a sandboxed one that I did my checks)

So am I missing something?

Thanks!

activities.message: I think if you invite a team member(read-only) in sandbox whitelisted hackers get incremented but I'm not 100% sure.
activities.markdown_message: I think if you invite a team member(read-only) in sandbox whitelisted hackers get incremented but I'm not 100% sure.

activities.message:
@emitrani Yes it did at the moment reported (I has sandboxed one that I used for  testing had `whitelisted_hackers` with non-zero content on GRAPHQL)

Also my response to @dirk explained it! Bottom line, you cant query GRAPHQL for any parameters  on a  team HANDLE (Either PRIVATE or SANDBOXED state) unless invited to participate. You will get (OBJECT NOT FOUND) and thats it. No `whitelisted_hackers` parameter disclosure.

Thanks all! Happy hacking and a hope the next one will have a bounty for all! (I think I had made an oversized analysis on this)

Cheers
**nismo**
activities.markdown_message:
@emitrani Yes it did at the moment reported (I has sandboxed one that I used for testing had whitelisted_hackers with non-zero content on GRAPHQL)

Also my response to @dirk explained it! Bottom line, you cant query GRAPHQL for any parameters on a team HANDLE (Either PRIVATE or SANDBOXED state) unless invited to participate. You will get (OBJECT NOT FOUND) and thats it. No whitelisted_hackers parameter disclosure.

Thanks all! Happy hacking and a hope the next one will have a bounty for all! (I think I had made an oversized analysis on this)

Cheers
nismo

vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:

Hi Team!

On Team object the parameter "i_cannot_create_jira_webhook_reasons" is not NULL and gets the following default states when called for all programs ["CANNOT_VIEW","FEATURE_GATED","PROGRAM_PERMISSION_REQUIRED"]

If a Company Program runs a Private Program or a Public On the "FEATURE_GATED" is missing (Since the feature is not gated anymore) and therefore an attacker can find if a Company is running a private program

POC

  • Company ██████ (not runnig private gives "i_cannot_create_jira_webhook_reasons":["CANNOT_VIEW","FEATURE_GATED","PROGRAM_PERMISSION_REQUIRED"]

  • Company █████████ (running private) gives "i_cannot_create_jira_webhook_reasons":["CANNOT_VIEW","PROGRAM_PERMISSION_REQUIRED"]

  • Even Company HackerOne (running public) gives "i_cannot_create_jira_webhook_reasons":["CANNOT_VIEW","PROGRAM_PERMISSION_REQUIRED"]

All private programs and public has an overriden "FEATURE_GATED" so you get the idea

Solutiion

NULL the value maybe

PS: Thanks to @jobert who encouraged me to search deeper after the #347383 duplicate!

Thanks
nismo

Impact

Knowing companies that run private programs on Hackerone

profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.
profile.name: HackerOne
